lines.text: Mr. Murphy. Just how much of Lincoln County are you after?
Well, Mr. Chisum came out here several years ago, put his name on everything he could. I've only been here a little while. Just getting started. Do you have anything to say to that, Mr. Chisum?

Well I don't favor talking to vermin, but I'll talk to you just this once. You're not just getting started. The line's been drawn. What Billy did balanced the books so far. But if one of your men cross my land or even touch one of my cows, or do anything to that store, I'm not going to the sheriff, the governor, or the president of the United States. I'm coming to see you.
Hmph. Mr. Chisum, that sounds like a threat.

[John Chisum belts Murphy, knocking him down with his right fist]
Wrong word. FACT!
You know, there's an old saying, Miss Sally. There's no law west of Dodge and no God west of the Pecos. Right, Mr. Chisum?
Wrong, Mr. Pepper. Because no matter where people go, sooner or later there's the law. And sooner or later they find God's already been there.
You're going to shoot us, ain't you Chisum?

I thought about it. Then I thought about something Henry Tunstall once said. He watched a man walk to the gallows... saw him hang. He said it was ghastly. Well, I've seen men hang, and that's the word - ghastly. You two are going to hang.
I think in some ways, the two of them are a lot alike.
Who?
Uncle John, Billy Bonney. Don't you think they are? Don't you?
Not in the important things.
Like what?

Well, Mr. Chisum's changed with the times. He doesn't like to let on, but he cares... about the people here and in town, about the Indians and the territory. Well, he's independent, and he likes to do things his own way, but he cares.
And Billy doesn't?
I guess he can't help it. But you heard him, all he cares about is gettin' those men.
In a way, doesn't it amount to the same thing?
No. Billy wants revenge. Mr. Chisum wants justice. There's a big difference.
Sheriff Brady, Jess Evans, this is Alex McSween. Uh, he's part of the family.
Howdy.
What does he do?
Well, he used to be a storekeeper and now he's my lawyer.
I prefer storekeepers!
Then don't ever get arrested.
I don't intend to.
Why get in a frazzle over Chisum? You turn me loose on him... there'll be a sudden funeral right here in Lincoln.
Uh-huh. Yours.
How's that?
Do you play chess?
Chess? What the hell has that got to do with Chisum?
Everything. You just leave him alone. I'll take care of Mr. Chisum.
That ain't gonna be easy.
You're right. But see, there's a fundamental difference between Mr. Chisum and me.
Yeah, what's that?
Mr. Chisum is a man who respects the law.
[Chuckles]
Around here, I'm the man who owns it.

And you good people witnessed the cowardly and cold-blooded murder of our beloved Sheriff Brady by Billy "the Kid" Bonney right over there. Governor Axtell has appointed a new sheriff, Dan Nodeen. He's offered a $200 award for the kid, and I'm adding a further reward of $1,000, dead or alive.
[Crowd murmurs "$1200"]
Sheriff here has formed his posse. Oh... Have you got anything you want to add to that, Sheriff?
Just this. I'm going to bring Bonney in. Now you people can either help me, or stay the hell out of my way!
John, I want to thank you for taking care of William.

[chuckles]
No, not me, Sally.
She's a wonderful girl, she's a worthwhile lamb.
Oh yeah, Henry, according to you, everybody's worthwhile.
God's children, John. Oh, William reminds me of someone.
A black sheep in the family, no doubt.

No, a young chap I never even talked to. Years ago in England this man very much like William killed a man in some senseless brawl. And I watched that young man walk to the gallows. And I saw him hang. Ghastly sight. There was nothing I could do to help that young lad.
I'm going down there, the rest of you cover me with your long guns.
[James Pepper follows Chisum]
I said cover me!
I know what you said, Mr. Chisum! But I ain't the rest of them!
It's nice to have you with us Big Casino!
Thanks, Little Casino.
Well, I'm upwind and I smell it on you.
Buffalo?
Death.
I see what you mean. Can it ever go away? That smell I mean.
Sure it can, with time, good company and patience.
I made you a promise, Mr. Tunstall. Now I'm making myself a promise. It says in the Bible, "The candle of the wicked shall be put out."
That man there, he's meaner than a gut shot grizzly.
So if you want these horses, I sell them to you. Did you bring some gold with you?
No.
Silver?
Just lead!
He's deader than a can of corned beef. You just had to kill him, huh?
A whole lot less trouble that way.
We may have to be neighbors, but I don't have to be neighborly.
What are you going to do?
What I had done twenty-five years ago. Pat, get the men out of South Camp. Trace, you round up everybody that can ride a horse or pull a trigger. Let's break out some Winchesters!
Would you like to hear my opinion, Mr. John Simpson Chisum?
Nope.

Well, my opinion is all this speechifying, store keeping, prayer-meeting don't amount to spit in the river. There's only one thing that's going to make this territory know who's bull of the woods... and sometime or sooner it's going to happen. And you know it.
Do I?

You do. It's just going to be you and Murphy, head-to-head and horn-to-horn... and one hell of a fight. But one of you has got to lose, so the other one walks away with the herd and the whole shebang. Now, that's my opinion.

[shouting]
Get some torches! I'll burn the son of a bitch out!

[lighting the sergeant's cigar]
Se rgeant, there's one thing I oughtta tell you; if you lay a hand on White Buffalo again, I'll kill ya'.
What's so funny?
This is the first time I ever put somebody else's brand on our own cows.

[after Garrett busts in a card game]
I sure left Garrett holding the short end. Big Casino.
[laughs]
I'm not so sure you won that game.
Sure I did.
Yeah. Sure you did.
